summaries.content:
Rate limiting was missing on the verification token-sending part of our login process. This is more directly raised by #230674, but a subsequent knock-on effect of this is that it would be theoretically possible (though extraordinarily difficult) to brute-force the verification process.

There is a limit of 5 attempts to get the verification token correct, after which the server deletes the token (though still responds the same way, so this isn't obvious).

By requesting a new verification token, a new random token is created and the attempt count is reset, allowing another 5 attempts (though against a different token).

Given 1 million possible tokens (6 digits) and 5 attempts, the likelihood of guessing correctly is a little more than 0.0005%. Without rate limiting, this makes it a reasonable possibility that you could eventually guess the token correctly. With the new rate limiting, this is likely to take a very long time.

By requesting a new verification token, a new random token is created and the attempt count is reset, allowing another 5 attempts (though against a different token).

Given 1 million possible tokens (6 digits) and 5 attempts, the likelihood of guessing correctly is a little more than 0.0005%. Without rate limiting, this makes it a reasonable possibility that you could eventually guess the token correctly. With the new rate limiting, this is likely to take a very long time.

summaries.content: Thanks for handling the report quickly and fairly :)
summaries.content_html: Thanks for handling the report quickly and fairly :)
